div.head:
Embleme 46. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Two Eagles come together, one from the East, the other from the West.

lg.l: Great Jove two Eagles out of Delphi sent
To th' East and Western parts, for this intent,
That hee the midle of the earth might find;
Which there returning, well resolv'd his mind.
But those two Eagles are two stones, which hast
One from the East, the other from the West.

div.head: Discourse 46.
div.ab:
Cicero in his booke of the nature of the Gods declares the most ancient-
Apollo to be the Sonne of Vulcan, and keeper of Athens: Which opinion,
if it be, as it ought, transferrd to an Allegory, is indeed most true; because
Vulcan produceth the Philosophicall Sol, which is Apollo. But it hath-
prævayld, that hee was borne of Jupiter; and that Latona having two
children in her wombe, Apollo and Diana, which shee conceivd of Ju
piter, Juno being jealous sent Python a Serpent of prodigious magni
tude and malice, to persecute and perplex her being great with child.-
The miserable woman after tedious wandrings was at length brought
by a Shipp to the Island Ortygia, to her sister Asteries, who therein
reigned: And that Island, being allmost all overflowed with the Sea,
gave place to Latona being in travell, whereupon it was called Delos,-
which before was 11 A: There therefore being in labour, first came forth
Diana, and shee did the office of a midwife to her mother labouring-
to bring forth her brother Apollo; From whence it came to passe-
that women going with Child did in the time of their labour
invoke her deity, and calld her either Lucina or Ilithya, be
cause shee shewd light to infants borne their eyes being opened:
Apollo therefore being borne and growne up slew Python the tor
menter of his mother wiht arrows, and killd the Cyclopes because-
they made lightening for Jupiter to destroy his Sonne Æsculapius,
whome Jupiter condemned to hell blasted with lightening, because
hee had restord Hippolytus to life being torne in peices by horses.
Wee have in many places demonstrated these things to be merely
Chymicall: For Latona, Cynthia, Apollo, and Python are requisites of
the art, which have such a relation one to the other, as hath been
declared; but these things being divulged in the writings of the most
ancient Poetts, as Orphens, Linus, Musæus, Homer, Ct. have given the
ignorant occasion to ascribe religion and veneration to Apollo: Here
upon Apollo is in many places of Europe and Asia worshipped,-
and innumerable temples erected to him; And especially at Delphos
hee had a temple to be worshipped by ancient religion, wherein a great
number of statues made of solid gold and silver or great weight-
and artifice was reposited by Kings and Princes, with other most
pretious gifts, which were hidden in sacred places for religion sake
by men of all degrees. Pausanias reports that a brazen Skeleton of
admirable artifice was hung at the top of the temple by Hippocrates.
That famous Tripos was allso consecrated to Apollo by Pelops, at the
time when hee marryed Hippodamia the daughter Œnomaus King
of Elis, which Tripos Mulciber made, and gave to Pelops: It was
erected in the midle of the temple, in which Pythia sitting
Discourse 46.
receiv'd the inspiration of the Devill gaping with a wide mouth, and then-
prophesyd, and gave responses to those that desird to know the events of things
to come: Delphos was indeed in Bœotica seated about the foot of Parnassus.-
Near to the temple was the divining fountaine, named Cassiotis, which, if bur
ning torches was brought to it did extinguish them: if they were removed
farre of, they were suddenly kindled, and tooke fire; and the water of-
that fountaine being dranke yeilded the virtue of divining, but not
withstanding the drinkers of that water were made of shorter life. Con
course therefore being made from all parts of Europe and Asia to the-
Delphicke Oracle, the Poets feigne that place, namely Parnassus to be-
in the midle of the earth, and that they proed by an example of Jupi
ter, who had experimented it by sending forth two Eagles: But this thing
not being supported by the reputation of history, it is not derogatory from the
truth, to ascribe it to Chymicall matters, especially Apollo being, as hath been-
declared, alltogether Chymicall by originall, though the Devill afterwards-
confirmed the superstition of men, and gave prophesyes under that name.
The two Eagles are two stones, whereof one comes from the East, the-
other from the West, which the Philosophers have many wayes demonstra
ted. Jupiter sends them forth, as his Ensigne=bearers. The Eagle seems in
deed a freind to Apollo or the Sunne, in proving her chickens at the Sunne,-
which if they cannot endure, Shee disownes them as illegitimate. Its feathers
being joyned with other things are sayd not to putrefy, and to devoure
the feathers of other birds, easily admitting gilding allso: By old age, or
sicknesse it dyes not, but by famine; For the upper beake growes soe
crooked that it cannot receive food: Which having cast off it plungeth it
selfe three times in a fountaine, and soe is sayd to returne to youth.-
Hereupon sayth the Psalmist: Your youth shall be renewed as the-
youth of an Eagle: This of all birds is never affected with Lightening:
It warrs with the dragon, which hunts after its eggs for the sake of-
them: All the endowments of whose nature have affoarded the Philo
sophers reason to prædicate the Eagle in their art, and assimilate the
stone to it, whereof innumerable examples being obvious in their-
books, wee will not here alleadye more. . . . . . . . . .
